title: Questions for Your hATTR Amyloidosis Appointment
author: Kristen Fischer

content: A visit to the doctor can be overwhelming because you may feel rushed, even if the doctor isn’t in a hurry. It’s a good idea to come prepared with a list of questions to ask. This can help you get the answers you need and get the best care for hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR).

Whether you’re seeing your regular doctor, a new specialist, or going for a second opinion , asking these questions can give you information you need to move forward. You may not need to ask every one, as some of these may not apply to you. Read through them to get a good idea of what to bring up during your visit.

content_blocks.text: A visit to the doctor can be overwhelming because you may feel rushed, even if the doctor isn’t in a hurry. It’s a good idea to come prepared with a list of questions to ask. This can help you get the answers you need and get the best care for hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR).

Whether you’re seeing your regular doctor, a new specialist, or going for a second opinion , asking these questions can give you information you need to move forward. You may not need to ask every one, as some of these may not apply to you. Read through them to get a good idea of what to bring up during your visit.

sections.heading: Questions About the Disease
content: Which symptoms can I, or should I, treat and how? Tell your doctor about all of your symptoms, even ones that may not be caused by hATTR. Your doctor can tell you how symptoms are treated, and if you should prioritize any over others. Also, the doctor can tell you about any potential drug interactions if you’re treating multiple symptoms with different medications and/or taking a drug for hATTR.

content_blocks.text: Which symptoms can I, or should I, treat and how? Tell your doctor about all of your symptoms, even ones that may not be caused by hATTR. Your doctor can tell you how symptoms are treated, and if you should prioritize any over others. Also, the doctor can tell you about any potential drug interactions if you’re treating multiple symptoms with different medications and/or taking a drug for hATTR.

sections.heading: What stage is my disease in?
content: There are four stages of hATTR. Stage 0 is when you don’t show symptoms, while stage I is when you have mild symptoms but can walk. Stage II means you’ll need help walking and have more problems throughout your body. Stage III includes needing a wheelchair or being confined to a bed with severe sensory, motor, and nerve problems throughout your body. Your doctor can tell you what stage you’re in and plan treatment based on that, along with other things.

What organs are affected by my hATTR? Your doctor can use tests to spot amyloid in your heart or other organs. The doctor will be able to tell you if the amyloid has joined together to form bunches, or fibrils, which can build up in tissues and organs. This is useful information to know because your treatment likely depends on the type of amyloid building up, and which organs and tissues it’s in.

sections.heading: Do my family members need genetic testing ?
content: hATTR is passed between family members. After you’re diagnosed with hATTR, you may want to know if anyone else in your family has it. If you have children, you may consider testing them to see if they have it. Treatment may work best when hATTR is found early, so knowing about it may allow you to help another family member. The disease gets worse over time.
Are there any symptoms that I should seek emergency care for? Though you may have multiple symptoms if you have hATTR, it’s a good idea to ask this so you know when to go to the hospital if needed.

sections.heading: Questions About Your Treatment
content: How will you determine my treatment strategy? Does it need to change at this time? The stage of your disease will probably guide what treatments your doctor recommends. Your doctor will look to see if your symptoms include polyneuropathy, which is nerve damage you may feel on both sides of your body that causes numbness , weakness, or burning. Symptoms can also include cardiomyopathy , a heart muscle disease. Some people have both symptoms. Your doctor will use that knowledge to develop a treatment plan.

content_blocks.text: How will you determine my treatment strategy? Does it need to change at this time? The stage of your disease will probably guide what treatments your doctor recommends. Your doctor will look to see if your symptoms include polyneuropathy, which is nerve damage you may feel on both sides of your body that causes numbness , weakness, or burning. Symptoms can also include cardiomyopathy , a heart muscle disease. Some people have both symptoms. Your doctor will use that knowledge to develop a treatment plan.

content: If you’re already being treated for hATTR, you may want to ask the doctor if they still think you should stay on that treatment, or if anything needs to change as your disease progresses.

Are there any new drugs that may be a good fit for me? New therapies are in the works, and a few medications have come on the market in recent years. Different medications are right for the varying stages of the disease. Your doctor will need to know your disease stage to see if there are new options to try or if you should make a switch from an existing treatment.
What can I expect from my treatment plan? Knowledge is power. Your doctor can tell you about any side effects you may have so you’ll know what to look out for.

How long will treatment last? There’s no cure for hATTR. Your treatment plan will be personalized based on the stage of your disease, symptoms, and other things. These things can help the doctor predict how long you may be on a certain treatment.

sections.heading: What side effects can I expect from my treatment?
content: These vary by treatment. For instance, inotersen (Tegsedi) can have serious side effects, so it may not be your doctor’s first choice. On the flip side, people who had hATTR with cardiomyopathy had no side effects during trials when they took tafamidis (Vyndamax, Vyndaqel). Once you know what your doctor wants you to take, they can advise you on what side effects you may have.
What tests do I need right now or in the near future? The disease gets worse over time, especially without treatment. Your doctor can let you know what tests you need to keep track of the disease.

How will I know if my treatment is working? You’ll see doctors on your care team regularly. The doctor may use tests to monitor the disease and ask you to keep them informed about symptoms to see if your treatment is helping.

sections.heading: Questions About Coordinating Care and Finances
content: What types of specialists do I need to see? Do you have recommendations on which ones may be right for me? This rare disease affects multiple organs, so you’ll see different specialists based on your needs. These may include a heart doctor ( cardiologist ), blood doctor ( hematologist ), brain doctor ( neurologist ), digestive tract and liver doctor ( gastroenterologist ), cancer doctor ( oncologist ), or genetic counselor. Ask your doctor what other specialists you’ll need. You can also ask if they have any personal recommendations if you haven’t found other specialists yet, or are thinking of switching.

content_blocks.text: What types of specialists do I need to see? Do you have recommendations on which ones may be right for me? This rare disease affects multiple organs, so you’ll see different specialists based on your needs. These may include a heart doctor ( cardiologist ), blood doctor ( hematologist ), brain doctor ( neurologist ), digestive tract and liver doctor ( gastroenterologist ), cancer doctor ( oncologist ), or genetic counselor. Ask your doctor what other specialists you’ll need. You can also ask if they have any personal recommendations if you haven’t found other specialists yet, or are thinking of switching.

sections.heading: If they’re in different offices, how will you coordinate care?
content: Because you’ll need to see multiple doctors, you may opt to get treatment in an amyloidosis center where all the specialists are in the same hospital. Otherwise, ask the doctor how you’ll manage appointments, and how to make sure the various health care professionals are sharing findings from tests and working together on what’s best for you.

Who will organize my care and remind me about follow-up visits? Do you use an electronic portal, emails, text messages, or regular mail? These are good questions to ask so you know what to expect. Your doctor can advise you on this based on their individual practice.

sections.heading: Is everything I need covered by my insurance? Who should I go to with those questions?
content: You’ll need a lot of care if you have hATTR, possibly from multiple practices and doctors. Ask the doctor, nurse, administrative professional, or your insurance company about your coverage.
If I need financial assistance with bills, who can help me? The administrative professionals working in the doctor’s office can help you with this, as can a care coordinator if you’re assigned one.

sections.heading: Get the Most From Your hATTR Doctor Visit
content: Along with the questions above, don't hesitate to ask other questions that pop up during your appointment. Your time with the doctor will probably be limited, so getting the information you need can mean that you leave feeling equipped to continue living with hATTR.

Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality: “Care Coordination.”
meta_description: Read some sample questions you may want to ask your doctor about hATTR symptoms and treatment, as well as financing your amyloidosis health care.
